answer_html: Thus, \(\displaystyle \phi(n) \nmid n-1\) since they do not share the factor of p.This is precisely what we wanted to show.
answer_latex:
Thus,
$\displaystyle \phi(n) \nmid n-1$ since they do not share the factor of
\emph{p}.This is precisely what we wanted to show.
hints_html:
It might help to prove the contrapositive:

Suppose that n is not square free, then \(\phi(n) \nmid n-1\)
hints_latex:
It might help to prove the contrapositive:

Suppose that \emph{n} is not square free, then $\phi(n) \nmid n-1$
hints_raw:
It might help to prove the contrapositive:

Suppose that ''n'' is not square free, then <math> \phi(n) \nmid n-1 </math>
sols_html:
The statement is true.

We use the hint and proceed by proving the contrapositive. Suppose that n is not squarefree. Then there is a prime p such that \(\displaystyle p^{2} \mid n\). Now, in this case, we have

\(\displaystyle p \mid \phi(p^{k}) = p^{k-1}(p-1)\)

where \(\displaystyle k \geq 2\). Further, write \(\displaystyle n = p^{k}m\) where m is coprime to p. Then

\(\displaystyle \phi(p^{k}) \mid \phi(p^{k})\phi(m) = \phi(p^{k}m) = \phi(n)\).

Hence

\(\displaystyle p \mid \phi(n)\).

However \(\displaystyle p \nmid n-1\) since \(\displaystyle n \equiv 0 \mod{p}\). Thus, \(\displaystyle \phi(n) \nmid n-1\) since they do not share the factor of p. This is precisely what we wanted to show.
sols_latex:
The statement is \textbf{true}.

We use the hint and proceed by proving the contrapositive. Suppose that
\emph{n} is not squarefree. Then there is a prime \emph{p} such that
$\displaystyle p^{2} \mid n$. Now, in this case, we have

$\displaystyle p \mid \phi(p^{k}) = p^{k-1}(p-1)$

where $\displaystyle k \geq 2$. Further, write
$\displaystyle n = p^{k}m$ where \emph{m} is coprime to \emph{p}. Then

$\displaystyle \phi(p^{k}) \mid \phi(p^{k})\phi(m) = \phi(p^{k}m) = \phi(n)$.

Hence

$\displaystyle p \mid \phi(n)$.

However $\displaystyle p \nmid n-1$ since
$\displaystyle n \equiv 0 \mod{p}$. Thus,
$\displaystyle \phi(n) \nmid n-1$ since they do not share the factor of
\emph{p}. This is precisely what we wanted to show.
sols_raw:
The statement is '''true'''.

We use the hint and proceed by proving the contrapositive. Suppose that ''n'' is not squarefree. Then there is a prime ''p'' such that <math> \displaystyle p^{2} \mid n </math>. Now, in this case, we have 

<math> \displaystyle p \mid \phi(p^{k}) = p^{k-1}(p-1)</math>

where <math> \displaystyle k \geq 2</math>. Further, write <math> \displaystyle n = p^{k}m</math> where ''m'' is coprime to ''p''. Then

<math> \displaystyle \phi(p^{k}) \mid \phi(p^{k})\phi(m) = \phi(p^{k}m) = \phi(n)</math>.

Hence

<math> \displaystyle p \mid \phi(n)</math>.

However <math> \displaystyle p \nmid n-1</math> since <math> \displaystyle n \equiv 0 \mod{p}</math>. Thus, <math> \displaystyle \phi(n) \nmid n-1</math> since they do not share the factor of ''p''. This is precisely what we wanted to show.
statement_html:
Prove or Disprove

For this problem, clearly indicate whether the statement is true or false then prove or disprove it.

If \(\displaystyle \phi(n)|n - 1\) then n is squarefree. (Here \(\displaystyle \phi\) is the Euler \(\displaystyle \phi\)-function.)
statement_raw:
'''Prove or Disprove'''

'''For this problem, ''clearly indicate'' whether the statement is ''true or false'' then prove or disprove it.'''

If <math>\displaystyle \phi(n)|n - 1</math> then ''n'' is squarefree. (Here <math>\displaystyle \phi</math> is the Euler <math>\displaystyle \phi</math>-function.)
